Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story:
I stood in the workshop, the scent of oil and metal clinging to my habit. The machines hummed quietly, waiting for my hands to keep them running smoothly. Next week’s shutdown was my window to perform the maintenance they desperately needed—cleaning, tightening, ensuring every gear and belt would last another season. The foreman had reminded me twice already: “We can’t afford any delays. Everything must be perfect before we restart.”

But as I glanced at the clock, the chapel bell began to toll. Morning prayers were about to begin, and as a nun, I was expected to be present, kneeling with my sisters, my mind and heart focused on devotion. The Mother Superior had spoken gently but firmly last night: “Our spiritual duties come first. The community looks to your example.”

My hands trembled, torn between the grease-stained tools and the rosary beads in my pocket. The machines needed me, but so did my faith community. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full presence, each unwilling to wait. The bell’s echo lingered as I stood frozen, caught between the call of duty and the call to prayer.
